Posts.Content: Sep 25, 2008 10:01AM FEB wrote: Jea, I saw for myself on the Thermogram. I am now so afraid of more radiation, that instead of any more mammos I have opted for thermography. I know that it is not accepted by mainstream medicine, but if read by someone who is experienced, as my doctor is, it  can be just as good at detecting tumors. It is basically an infrared camera that takes photos of the breasts and looks for vascular irrregularities to detect cancer. My left, good breast was blue in color, my right was red and orange, showing how hot it still is. What I also like about this is that it is totally painless, and I did not want to get my breast smashed again, since it is so tender. I am not advocating this for anyone else, I just feel it is the right choice for me. A mammo did not find my tumor, I did, so I will continue to check my breasts for any changes, have the therms, and monitor everything else with a doctor I found who is into alternatives. Needless to say, my onc is not happy, but I have no plans to go back to her anyway, unless I absolutely have to because that place is so depressing!
Posts.Title: Radiation and Rib Pain tomatojuice BarbW

Posts.Content: Sep 27, 2008 05:34AM - edited Sep 27, 2008 05:36AM by FEB Nena The thermograph does not show a mass like mammos. It shows the vascular system. They look for symmnetry in both breasts to see what is consistant in how the blood flows. Since a tumor has to be fed by extra blood flow, it will show up as having extra feeders running to it. My doc has  a really good website that explains it. Go to drnick.net and check it out. This doctor was recommended to me by my chiropractor. She had met him at some of the seminars she regularly attends.
Posts.Title: Radiation and Rib Pain tomatojuice BarbW

Posts.Content: Sep 25, 2008 06:38AM FEB wrote: I still have rib pain, mildly, and it has been 9 months since I finished rads. At 6 mo. I went and had a thermograph, and I could not believe how hot my breast still was. I will do another one in  a couple of months. I hope it shows some cooling. At least I feel I have seen proof that the effects of the radiation are still there, and this pain is not a figment of my imagination. By the way, I had very little surface damage.
Posts.Title: Radiation and Rib Pain tomatojuice BarbW

Posts.Content: Apr 19, 2008 08:14AM FEB wrote: Anger was the hardest thing for me to deal with, and no one could help me through it. It is something I had to totally get through  on my own. I didn't want anyone to call me for weeks. I took a lot of long walks with my IPOD. I assume you are English because you say MUM, so my advice is to buy your mom an MP3 loaded with Sting's music. His mom died of BC and his music really spoke to me. Tell her to just go out and have a good walk with Sting. Not only will this help her physically, it will help her get her head together. My two favorite albums are "Sacred Love" and "Mercury Rising". Even now, when I am past treatment, I walk to his music and it "heals my soul" (Sting's words from Lithium sunset).
Posts.Title: how to deal with anger prycylla althea

Posts.Content: Mar 2, 2009 03:36PM - edited Mar 2, 2009 03:47PM by FEB I had the same dx as you bluejay. I had no chemo, 33 rads including 5 boosts at the end. I never had any fatigue. I took a walk after every treatment, and tried to eat very healthy. My radiologist said that I am proof that exercising through treatments minimizes side effects. I had only mild burning too. Even though it was easy for me physically, emotionally, I was a wreck. I had a lot of meltdowns because the whole thing scared me so much. I still wish I had said no to rads. Since my nodes were clear and I had wide margins, I just do not think it was worth the expense and trauma in my case. I also decided against arimidex which, may be another reason I had an easier time physically.
Posts.Title: RADIATION FATIGUE - POLL bluejay1 Siciliana

Posts.Content: Jul 1, 2008 06:03AM FEB wrote: I agree with Rose. Pretend you are on a vacation. Yeah, you will miss your family a lot, but take the time to pamper yourself. Explore your new surroundings and walk a lot. I had no fatique from the rads because I walked everyday after treatment, even during a very cold and snowy Chicago winter. The fresh air was invigorating. It has been proven that exercise really helps with the SE's from rads. The walking also helped me get my head together. It took a while, but walking helped me to make peace with the whole damn situation. I also did it all with no drugs. Yeah it was hard to sleep sometimes, but I started taking melatonin, which is a natural relaxant and an antioxidant. I read that the ingredients in some of the prescribed drugs can actually feed cancer so I stayed away from them all. Melatonin has no such effects. I guess you are lucky that you will only go for 3 weeks. My treatments lasted 2 months because I had days off for Thanksgiving and Christmas. I thought it was never going to end. Boy did I cry tears of joy the last day! I still wish I had never done rads because I worry about the longterm effects, but I guess I got through it. I am still really mad at my doctors for pushing it so hard without explaining it all to me. I still think they over treat us when we have early stage tumors.
Posts.Title: I'm desperately unhappy just now. jacquibutterfly dalycity
Healthy weight to lower risk alohamomof3 NancyD
Healthy weight to lower risk alohamomof3 NancyD

Posts.Content: Sep 18, 2008 03:18PM FEB wrote: My rad onc was okay with me taking supplements during rads. She said just do not over do it. I took a multi, omega 3, vit e, and melatonin to help me sleep instead of the drug she prescribed. She kept commenting on how well I was coming through it. My skin was only slightly red, and I never had any fatigue. I walked every day, even in the cold and snow, and this really kept my energy up, and helped me to clear my head of all the anxiety of rads. I keep reading more and more doctors say that supplements can have a positive effect on treatments. I think I am living proof!
Posts.Title: Antioxidants during radiation jea1013 Karen56

Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2008 08:09PM FEB wrote: I forgot to add one more thing. I stopped wearing a bra after surgery because it was irritating, especially under my arm. I wore cotton camisoles all the time. They were easy on my skin, and gave me some support. Fortunately, I am not that big busted!
Posts.Title: Looking for a February Rad Team debbbyb twirlgirl

Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2008 08:06PM FEB wrote: I just finished rads, and thought you might like to hear about my experience. I too was freaked about the whole thing. I hated the idea of tatoos. How many more marks do I have to deal with?!!! But mine are really small, and my eyes are so bad I can't see them anyway! It seemed like the treatment would go on forever, especially because it was through Christmas and New Years, but  I finished and feel great, so I'd like to pass on what I did. First, bring some music to listen to. My techs were great about putting my music on the CD player and playing it loud. It was a great escape. After the treatments, I drank a lot of water, and ate an apple on my way to the river walk in our town, where I walked every day, even in the cold and snow. If it rained, I went home and did an exercise DVD. I never got fatiqued at all. My radiologist's are so impressed with my energy level, that they are using me to encourage others to exercise through it. I realize that I am very lucky because I did not have chemo, but I think I would have tried to walk through that too. It not only helped me feel great physically, it helped me deal with the emotional roller coaster, that I had a really hard time getting off of. ALso, my skin looks great. I had a little redness under my arm and a little itching but that was all. I took a multivitamin some omega 3. I know this is controvesial, but my radiologist said it would be okay. I also used a lot of cremes, from day one, both what they gave me and my own. I took a lot of baths with aloe, putting the wask cloth on my breast instead of immersing them. I also found a great cream at Sam's club with vitamin E the day I finished and I put that on liberally several times a day. My breast is looking and feeling great and it will be only a week tomorrow since I finished. I know that everyone is different, and a lot depends on your skin and the radiation plan they set up for you, but I went into this determined that I was not going to let it get to me. Attitude is everything. Good luck to all of you just starting! You can do it!
Posts.Title: Looking for a February Rad Team debbbyb twirlgirl

Posts.Content: Jul 3, 2008 07:22AM FEB wrote: Light My advice is to not spend too much time reading about BC. It will only make you more nervous. Just go on a need to know basis. Beesie explained to you about a path report and biopsies. That is all you need to know right now. You trusted your instincts and they were right. Be pround of yourself and continue to listen to that inner voice. It will help you to make the right decisions. And finally, from this moment on, concentrate on getting yourself healthy again. Don't worry about BC, think about the future. Don't look back, except to learn is my favorite adage.
Posts.Title: hi, new here -> shocking story! ?? lightacandle lightacandle

Posts.Content: Mar 8, 2008 09:15AM FEB wrote: I am with you ladies on all the pink stuff. Have you checked out the bcaction.org website? They will tell you where all the money for the pink stuff goes and a lot more. I will never do any of the walks because I am not convinced the money goes to people who are suffering now and to research for a true cure-which should include preventing this damn disease to begin with. I do believe it can be prevented. I am tired of my doctors pushing drugs with bad SE's but refuse to look at holistic means of prevention. I believe that our food is a major reason for the increase in BC and it is time some of the money gets spent looking into this. We need to get rid of the stuff that causes cancer. But of course, think of how much money the cancer industry will lose if they actually find a cure or learn how to prevent this in the first place. Now if I was assured that the money I raised in a walk would go directly to survivors like you Luann, who have children to raise and limited resources, I would be all there, but as long as it continues to go to these mysterious studies that have not improved cancer treatment much or educated the country on prevention, I want no part of it. My prayers are with you all for a happy and healthy outcome.
Posts.Title: I hate pink ribbons, but.......... Watson Fitztwins

Posts.Content: Jan 24, 2008 08:34PM FEB wrote: Donna I just finished radiation two days ago, so I can still remember what you are going through. You need an escape plan. I decided to walk a lot and listen to music. Even though it is really cold here (Naperville, Il), I kept walking. It really helped me to get my head together. It also had fringe benefits. I never got tired, lost 10 pounds and feel great. I also ate really healthy foods only. I was lucky that I did not need chemo, but I was a basket case none the less. Also, don't be afraid to vent. Cry, get mad, and tell those close to you exactly how you feel. Do not hold it in. I did not feel whole again until my victory walk on the last day of radiation, but that day was wonderful! I give you all my blessings and pray that you will have good news!
